f041c2423614.fact: Microsoft Corporation is an American multinational technology conglomerate headquartered in Redmond, Washington.

93150bba44a6.fact: Founded in 1975, the company became influential in the rise of personal computers through software like Windows, and has since expanded to Internet services, cloud computing, artificial intelligence, video gaming, and other fields.

ce11076fe64c.key: Often described as a Big Tech company, Microsoft
ce11076fe64c.fact: Often described as a Big Tech company, Microsoft is the largest software company by revenue, one of the most valuable public companies, and one of the most valuable brands globally.

23721b506ecb.key: The company's 1986 initial public offering (IPO) a
23721b506ecb.fact: The company's 1986 initial public offering (IPO) and subsequent rise in its share price created three billionaires and an estimated 12,000 millionaires among Microsoft employees.

0e8850d75a84.fact: He oversaw the then-largest of Microsoft's corporate acquisitions in Skype Technologies in 2011, an increased focus on hardware that led to its first in-house PC line, the Surface, in 2012, and the formation of Microsoft Mobile through Nokia.

1fc3ba7f83f9.fact: Since Satya Nadella took over as CEO in 2014, the company has changed focus towards cloud computing, as well as its acquisition of LinkedIn for $26.2 billion in 2016.

91d50b6cc09d.fact: Under Nadella's direction, the company has expanded its video gaming business to support the Xbox brand, establishing the Microsoft Gaming division in 2022 and the acquisition of Activision Blizzard for $68.7 billion in 2023.

afd9b2c97dcb.fact: Its best-known software products are the Windows line of operating systems and the Microsoft Office and Microsoft 365 suite of productivity applications, which most notably include the Word word processor, Excel spreadsheet editor, and the PowerPoint presentation program.

30c43a0ccca9.fact: Its flagship hardware products are the Surface lineup of personal computers and Xbox video game consoles, the latter of which includes the Xbox network; the company also provides a range of consumer Internet services such as Bing web search, the MSN web portal, the Outlook.com (Hotmail) email service and the Microsoft Store.

d4f0772655a5.fact: The .NET Foundation is an organization incorporated on March 31, 2014, by Microsoft to improve open-source software development and collaboration around the .NET Framework.

4c20751085ab.fact: The foundation is license-agnostic, and projects that come to the foundation are free to choose any open-source license, as defined by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).

e45812840a28.fact: As of May 2020, it is the steward of 556 active projects, including: .NET, Entity Framework (EF), Managed Extensibility Framework (MEF), MSBuild, NuGet, Orchard CMS and WorldWide Telescope.

dec05ae79f78.fact: Many of these projects are also listed under Outercurve Foundation project galleries.

f84672f3c85a.fact: 100% renewable energy is the goal of using fully renewable resources for all electric energy consumption.

ace2b13eac55.key: renewable energy for electricity, heating, cooling
ace2b13eac55.fact: 100% renewable energy for electricity, heating, cooling and transport is motivated by greenhouse gas emissions, pollution, and other environmental issues, as well as economic and energy security concerns.

140bf4d31334.key: Shifting the total global primary energy supply to
140bf4d31334.fact: Shifting the total global primary energy supply to renewable sources requires a transition of the energy system, since most of today's energy is derived from non-renewable fossil fuels.

3a21900848dd.fact: Research into this topic is fairly new, with few studies published before 2009, but has gained increasing attention in recent years.

fda6938fbc0a.fact: A cross-sectoral, holistic approach is seen as an important feature of 100% renewable energy systems and is based on the assumption "that the best solutions can be found only if one focuses on the synergies between the sectors" of the energy system such as electricity, heat, transport or industry.

d57fdac614db.fact: Nikola Tesla (10 July 1856 – 7 January 1943) was a Serbian-American engineer, futurist, and inventor.

90aafca292dc.fact: In 1884, he migrated to the United States, where he became a naturalized citizen.

e40241474f71.fact: His AC induction motor and related polyphase AC patents, licensed by Westinghouse Electric in 1888, earned him a considerable amount of money and became the cornerstone of the polyphase system, which Westinghouse marketed.

6008e1be1d8a.fact: Tesla became well known as an inventor and demonstrated his achievements to celebrities and wealthy patrons at his lab.

8cbef3f8bfc3.fact: In 1893, he made pronouncements on the possibility of wireless communication with his devices.

d6a25ba2486b.fact: He died in New York City in January 1943.

bf950b0a82ab.fact: In 2013, Time named Tesla one of the 100 most significant figures of all time.

332ff1fe442c.key: Summit Conference of Heads of State or Government
332ff1fe442c.fact: Summit Conference of Heads of State or Government of the Non-Aligned Movement (Serbo-Croatian: Конференција шефова држава или влада несврстаних земаља / Konferencija šefova država ili vlada nesvrstanih zemalja, Macedonian: Конференција на шефови на држави или влади на неврзани земји, Slovene: Konferenca voditeljev držav ali vlad neuvrščenih držav) on 1–6 September 1961 in Belgrade, Yugoslavia was the first conference of the Non-Aligned Movement.
332ff1fe442c.source: Wikipedia: 1st Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement

02488b0bce2c.key: A major contributing factor to the organization of
02488b0bce2c.fact: A major contributing factor to the organization of the conference was the process of decolonization of a number of African countries in the 1960s.
02488b0bce2c.source: Wikipedia: 1st Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement

e754394d9e4b.key: Twenty-five countries in total participated in Bel
e754394d9e4b.fact: Twenty-five countries in total participated in Belgrade Conference, while 3 countries, Bolivia, Brazil and Ecuador, were observers.
e754394d9e4b.source: Wikipedia: 1st Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement

326c5ae49df1.fact: One of the issues was division of the newly independent countries over the Congo Crisis which led to a rift and creation of the conservative and anti-radical Brazzaville Group and radical nationalist Casablanca Group.
326c5ae49df1.source: Wikipedia: 1st Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement

091b96705d5d.key: All members of the Casablanca Group attended the c
091b96705d5d.fact: All members of the Casablanca Group attended the conference, including Algeria, Ghana, Guinea, Mali, Morocco and the United Arab Republic, while none of the Brazzaville Group was present.
091b96705d5d.source: Wikipedia: 1st Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement

eed93cdf0753.fact: The summit was followed by the 2nd Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement in Cairo in 1964.
eed93cdf0753.source: Wikipedia: 1st Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement

1a3a5b46d7a6.key: The 1962 Cairo Conference on the Problems of Devel
1a3a5b46d7a6.fact: The 1962 Cairo Conference on the Problems of Developing Countries was a direct follow-up of the Belgrade Summit at which Brazil, Ethiopia, India, Senegal and Yugoslavia will work on preparation for the upcoming UNCTAD conference of the ECOSOC.
1a3a5b46d7a6.source: Wikipedia: 1st Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement

05aafd37a79a.fact: 2244 Tesla, provisional designation 1952 UW1, is a carbonaceous asteroid from the central region of the asteroid belt, approximately 25 kilometers in diameter.

c53af1c00903.key: A Bézier curve ( BEH-zee-ay, French pronunciation:
c53af1c00903.fact: A Bézier curve ( BEH-zee-ay, French pronunciation: [bezje]) is a parametric curve used in computer graphics and related fields.

2c4942d761c7.fact: Usually the curve is intended to approximate a real-world shape that otherwise has no mathematical representation or whose representation is unknown or too complicated.

79e1d7aea052.fact: The Bézier curve is named after French engineer Pierre Bézier (1910–1999), who used it in the 1960s for designing curves for the bodywork of Renault cars.

2b6808ad7ab2.fact: The Bézier triangle is a special case of the latter.

5aeaeef7e956.fact: In vector graphics, Bézier curves are used to model smooth curves that can be scaled indefinitely.

00de599b23b3.fact: "Paths", as they are commonly referred to in image manipulation programs, are combinations of linked Bézier curves.

13872c0118a4.fact: Paths are not bound by the limits of rasterized images and are intuitive to modify.

15f43edba2fd.fact: Bézier curves are also used in the time domain, particularly in animation, user interface design and smoothing cursor trajectory in eye gaze-controlled interfaces.

54c9527732fd.fact: Adobe After Effects is a digital effects, motion graphics, and compositing application developed by Adobe Inc.; it is used for animation and in the post-production process of film making, video games and television production.

37364e361ada.fact: In 2019, the program won an Academy Award for scientific and technical achievement.

1c36cf1db7e5.key: Adobe Flash (formerly Macromedia Flash and FutureS
1c36cf1db7e5.fact: Adobe Flash (formerly Macromedia Flash and FutureSplash) is a mostly discontinued multimedia software platform used for production of animations, rich internet applications, desktop applications, mobile apps, mobile games, and embedded web browser video players.

d945f9357c16.fact: Adobe Illustrator is a vector graphics editor and design software developed and marketed by Adobe.

8242a8b2a88d.key: Along with Creative Cloud (Adobe's shift to a mont
8242a8b2a88d.fact: Along with Creative Cloud (Adobe's shift to a monthly or annual subscription service delivered over the Internet), Illustrator CC was released.

be93fb858d93.fact: The latest version, Illustrator 2026, was released on October 28, 2025, and is the 30th generation in the product line.

02cc8dc4d04d.fact: Adobe Photoshop is a raster graphics editor developed and published by Adobe for Windows and macOS.

5e9a151e5610.fact: Photoshop's naming scheme was initially based on version numbers.

991d53bde78a.fact: However, in October 2002 (following the introduction of Creative Suite branding), each new version of Photoshop was designated with "CS" plus a number; e.g., the eighth major version of Photoshop was Photoshop CS and the ninth was Photoshop CS2.

5136fd15d99f.fact: Photoshop CS3 through CS6 were also distributed in two different editions: Standard and Extended.

a25a22813f33.key: With the introduction of the Creative Cloud brandi
a25a22813f33.fact: With the introduction of the Creative Cloud branding in June 2013 (and, in turn, the change of the "CS" suffix to "CC"), Photoshop's licensing scheme was changed to that of subscription model.

d306841f4bf8.fact: Historically, Photoshop was bundled with additional software such as Adobe ImageReady, Adobe Fireworks, Adobe Bridge, Adobe Device Central and Adobe Camera RAW.

d1f776c5ccf9.fact: Collectively, they are branded as "The Adobe Photoshop Family".

6af177ea1703.fact: In mathematics, an affine space is a geometric structure that generalizes some of the properties of Euclidean spaces in such a way that these are independent of the concepts of distance and measure of angles, keeping only the properties related to parallelism and ratio of lengths for parallel line segments.

584de4be2178.fact: Affine space is the setting for affine geometry.

86766018a752.key: As in Euclidean space, the fundamental objects in
86766018a752.fact: As in Euclidean space, the fundamental objects in an affine space are called points, which can be thought of as locations in the space without any size or shape: zero-dimensional.

98018906f37f.key: Through any pair of points an infinite straight li
98018906f37f.fact: Through any pair of points an infinite straight line can be drawn, a one-dimensional set of points; through any three points that are not collinear, a two-dimensional plane can be drawn; and, in general, through k + 1 points in general position, a k-dimensional flat or affine subspace can be drawn.

92f723cf3c2d.key: Given any line, a line parallel to it can be drawn
92f723cf3c2d.fact: Given any line, a line parallel to it can be drawn through any point in the space, and the equivalence class of parallel lines are said to share a direction.

93a4215cb09c.key: Unlike for vectors in a vector space, in an affine
93a4215cb09c.fact: Unlike for vectors in a vector space, in an affine space there is no distinguished point that serves as an origin.

b7faf59066a8.key: However, for any affine space, an associated vecto
b7faf59066a8.fact: However, for any affine space, an associated vector space can be constructed from the differences between start and end points, which are called free vectors, displacement vectors, translation vectors or simply translations.

e70fb92804ee.key: While points cannot be arbitrarily added together,
e70fb92804ee.fact: While points cannot be arbitrarily added together, it is meaningful to take affine combinations of points: weighted sums with numerical coefficients summing to 1, resulting in another point.

b2997c1bdb66.key: When considered as a point, the zero vector
b2997c1bdb66.fact: When considered as a point, the zero vector is called the origin.

0fc00fb9279a.key: In finite dimensions, such an affine subspace
0fc00fb9279a.fact: In finite dimensions, such an affine subspace is the solution set of an inhomogeneous linear system.

8a6b91912773.key: The displacement vectors for that affine space
8a6b91912773.fact: The displacement vectors for that affine space are the solutions of the corresponding homogeneous linear system, which is a linear subspace.

898628f80304.key: The dimension of an affine space
898628f80304.fact: The dimension of an affine space is defined as the dimension of the vector space of its translations.

eebdc8c8e05e.key: An affine space of dimension one
eebdc8c8e05e.fact: An affine space of dimension one is an affine line.

24749d3fd535.key: An affine subspace of dimension n – 1 in an affine
24749d3fd535.fact: An affine subspace of dimension n – 1 in an affine space or a vector space of dimension n is an affine hyperplane.

82d4de9de6cf.key: In Euclidean geometry, an affine transformation or
82d4de9de6cf.fact: In Euclidean geometry, an affine transformation or affinity (from the Latin, affinis, "connected with") is a geometric transformation that preserves lines and parallelism, but not necessarily Euclidean distances and angles.

aceea49ac76f.fact: More generally, an affine transformation is an automorphism of an affine space (Euclidean spaces are specific affine spaces), that is, a function which maps an affine space onto itself while preserving both the dimension of any affine subspaces (meaning that it sends points to points, lines to lines, planes to planes, and so on) and the ratios of the lengths of parallel line segments.

16a42170f4bb.fact: If X is the point set of an affine space, then every affine transformation on X can be represented as the composition of a linear transformation on X and a translation of X.

51a2a92773b3.fact: Thus, every linear transformation is affine, but not every affine transformation is linear.

588c8ee5ee41.key: Viewing an affine space as the complement of a hyp
588c8ee5ee41.fact: Viewing an affine space as the complement of a hyperplane at infinity of a projective space, the affine transformations are the projective transformations of that projective space that leave the hyperplane at infinity invariant, restricted to the complement of that hyperplane.

3854e64e8e0a.key: A generalization of an affine transformation
3854e64e8e0a.fact: A generalization of an affine transformation is an affine map (or affine homomorphism or affine mapping) between two (potentially different) affine spaces over the same field k.

37e01eb13895.fact: A map f : X → Z is an affine map if there exists a linear map mf : V → W such that mf (x − y) = f (x) − f (y) for all x, y in X.

bfcb84896e04.key: In mathematics, an affine algebraic plane curve
bfcb84896e04.fact: In mathematics, an affine algebraic plane curve is the zero set of a polynomial in two variables.

8446bb60dd10.fact: A projective algebraic plane curve is the zero set in a projective plane of a homogeneous polynomial in three variables.

5b3f1bb7d1a6.fact: These two operations are each inverse to the other; therefore, the phrase algebraic plane curve is often used without specifying explicitly whether it is the affine or the projective case that is considered.

688f7ac0f753.key: If the defining polynomial of a plane algebraic cu
688f7ac0f753.fact: If the defining polynomial of a plane algebraic curve is irreducible, then one has an irreducible plane algebraic curve.

8972124ce0bf.fact: Otherwise, the algebraic curve is the union of one or several irreducible curves, called its components, that are defined by the irreducible factors.

2553b7b67485.fact: More generally, an algebraic curve is an algebraic variety of dimension one.

ca311ddeda51.key: In some contexts, an algebraic set of dimension on
ca311ddeda51.fact: In some contexts, an algebraic set of dimension one is also called an algebraic curve, but this will not be the case in this article.

792344077823.fact: Equivalently, an algebraic curve is an algebraic variety that is birationally equivalent to an irreducible algebraic plane curve.

f8c0c588e137.fact: If the curve is contained in an affine space or a projective space, one can take a projection for such a birational equivalence.

5b20e2256323.fact: However, some properties are not kept under birational equivalence and must be studied on non-plane curves.

d17f8e899621.fact: A non-plane curve is often called a space curve or a skew curve.

cf5f65126b4f.fact: Allegro is a software library for video game development.

20b43b41cfa1.fact: The library is written in the C programming language and designed to be used with C, C++, or Objective-C, with bindings available for Python, Lua, Scheme, D, Go, and other languages.

058e7a23cc1d.key: It can run also on top of Simple DirectMedia Layer
058e7a23cc1d.fact: It can run also on top of Simple DirectMedia Layer which is used to run Allegro programs in web browser using Emscripten.

a354b65bf2fe.key: Released under the terms of the zlib license, Alle
a354b65bf2fe.fact: Released under the terms of the zlib license, Allegro is free and open source software.

15247b3ef223.key: In computer-aided geometric design a control point
15247b3ef223.fact: In computer-aided geometric design a control point is a member of a set of points used to determine the shape of a spline curve or, more generally, a surface or higher-dimensional object.

f368412733d5.fact: Some would reasonably insist, in order to give intuitive geometric meaning to the word "control", that the blending functions form a partition of unity, i.e., that the ⁠ ϕ i {\displaystyle \phi _{i}} ⁠ are nonnegative and sum to one.

3afc47fe8dc4.key: In numerical analysis, a B-spline (short for basis
3afc47fe8dc4.fact: In numerical analysis, a B-spline (short for basis spline) is a type of spline function designed to have minimal support (overlap) for a given degree, smoothness, and set of breakpoints (knots that partition its domain), making it a fundamental building block for all spline functions of that degree.

d7c16cf7ffe7.fact: A B-spline is defined as a piecewise polynomial of order n {\displaystyle n} , meaning a degree of n − 1 {\displaystyle n-1} .

688a5abac6ae.fact: The concept of B-splines traces back to the 19th century, when Nikolai Lobachevsky explored similar ideas at Kazan University in Russia, though the term "B-spline" was coined by Isaac Jacob Schoenberg in 1967, reflecting their role as basis functions.

7f92eba7fc45.fact: B-splines are widely used in fields like computer-aided design (CAD) and computer graphics, where they shape curves and surfaces through a set of control points, as well as in data analysis for tasks like curve fitting and numerical differentiation of experimental data.

3daff8067711.fact: In mathematics, a basis function is an element of a particular basis for a function space.

eb5b5feca82f.key: In finite-dimensional vector spaces this represent
eb5b5feca82f.fact: In finite-dimensional vector spaces this representation is purely algebraic and involves only finitely many basis functions, whereas in infinite-dimensional settings it typically takes the form of an infinite series whose convergence depends on the topology of the space.

751d13184f59.key: In numerical analysis and approximation theory, ba
751d13184f59.fact: In numerical analysis and approximation theory, basis functions are also called blending functions, because of their use in interpolation: In this application, a mixture of the basis functions provides an interpolating function (with the "blend" depending on the evaluation of the basis functions at the data points).

7e243ce316f8.fact: Computer-aided design (CAD) is the use of computers (or workstations) to aid in the creation, modification, analysis, or optimization of a design.

e9dd4d593b95.fact: This software is used to increase the productivity of the designer, improve the quality of design, improve communications through documentation, and to create a database for manufacturing.

0a64d77fd0b5.fact: CAD output is often in the form of electronic files for print, machining, or other manufacturing operations.

3341faf49aad.key: The terms computer-aided drafting (CAD) and comput
3341faf49aad.fact: The terms computer-aided drafting (CAD) and computer-aided design and drafting (CADD) are also used.

d9adb3368d0d.key: Its use in designing electronic systems is
d9adb3368d0d.fact: Its use in designing electronic systems is known as electronic design automation (EDA).

133167429331.fact: In mechanical design it is known as mechanical design automation (MDA), which includes the process of creating a technical drawing with the use of computer software.

b5fde512c765.fact: CAD is also widely used to produce computer animation for special effects in movies, advertising and technical manuals, often called DCC digital content creation.

cd56f114bf2b.key: The modern ubiquity and power of computers means t
cd56f114bf2b.fact: The modern ubiquity and power of computers means that even perfume bottles and shampoo dispensers are designed using techniques unheard of by engineers of the 1960s.

df237c382f7b.key: The design of geometric models for object shapes,
df237c382f7b.fact: The design of geometric models for object shapes, in particular, is occasionally called computer-aided geometric design (CAGD).

1384d8d035b4.key: In technical applications of 3D computer graphics
1384d8d035b4.fact: In technical applications of 3D computer graphics (CAx) such as computer-aided design and computer-aided manufacturing, surfaces are one way of representing objects.

7332d11802fd.fact: The other ways are wireframe (lines and curves) and solids.

6cc63fcd110d.fact: Point clouds are also sometimes used as temporary ways to represent an object, with the goal of using the points to create one or more of the three permanent representations.

ce3f5934f5df.key: In geometry, the convex hull, convex envelope or c
ce3f5934f5df.fact: In geometry, the convex hull, convex envelope or convex closure of a shape is the smallest convex set that contains it.

ff77bfd8a70f.fact: Convex hulls of open sets are open, and convex hulls of compact sets are compact.

69630b62540e.fact: Every compact convex set is the convex hull of its extreme points.

1aaaaf1876af.fact: The convex hull operator is an example of a closure operator, and every antimatroid can be represented by applying this closure operator to finite sets of points.

47c0a19636f1.key: The algorithmic problems of finding the convex hul
47c0a19636f1.fact: The algorithmic problems of finding the convex hull of a finite set of points in the plane or other low-dimensional Euclidean spaces, and its dual problem of intersecting half-spaces, are fundamental problems of computational geometry.

ed7daeb157cd.fact: Geometry is a branch of mathematics concerned with properties of space such as the distance, shape, size, and relative position of figures.

709d6fd975fa.key: A mathematician who works in the field of geometry
709d6fd975fa.fact: A mathematician who works in the field of geometry is called a geometer.

a332aa46973a.fact: Until the 19th century, geometry was almost exclusively devoted to Euclidean geometry, which includes the notions of point, line, plane, distance, angle, surface, and curve, as fundamental concepts.

afd644cb9be7.key: Originally developed to model the physical world,
afd644cb9be7.fact: Originally developed to model the physical world, geometry has applications in almost all sciences, and also in art, architecture, and other activities that are related to graphics.

20b6f94859ab.key: Geometry also has applications in areas of mathema
20b6f94859ab.fact: Geometry also has applications in areas of mathematics that are apparently unrelated.

00d11a5c3033.key: For example, methods of algebraic geometry
00d11a5c3033.fact: For example, methods of algebraic geometry are fundamental in Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, a problem that was stated in terms of elementary arithmetic, and remained unsolved for several centuries.

7a86881180c0.key: One of the oldest such discoveries
7a86881180c0.fact: One of the oldest such discoveries is Carl Friedrich Gauss's Theorema Egregium ("remarkable theorem") that asserts roughly that the Gaussian curvature of a surface is independent from any specific embedding in a Euclidean space.

d62a66d19f23.key: The geometry that underlies general relativity
d62a66d19f23.fact: The geometry that underlies general relativity is a famous application of non-Euclidean geometry.

fd9a00d8e9eb.key: This enlargement of the scope of geometry led to a
fd9a00d8e9eb.fact: This enlargement of the scope of geometry led to a change of meaning of the word "space", which originally referred to the three-dimensional space of the physical world and its model provided by Euclidean geometry; presently a geometric space, or simply a space is a mathematical structure on which some geometry is defined.

40b96434ad92.fact: The International Standard Book Number (ISBN) is a numeric commercial book identifier that is intended to be unique.

39cb019411c8.fact: A different ISBN is assigned to each separate edition and variation of a publication, but not to a simple reprinting of an existing item.

6a69b7e00eef.fact: The ISBN is ten digits long if assigned before 2007, and thirteen digits long if assigned on or after 1 January 2007.

64bad938cd16.key: The method of assigning an ISBN
64bad938cd16.fact: The method of assigning an ISBN is nation-specific and varies between countries, often depending on how large the publishing industry is within a country.

4ab37125d506.key: The first version of the ISBN identification forma
4ab37125d506.fact: The first version of the ISBN identification format was devised in 1967, based upon the 9-digit Standard Book Numbering (SBN) created in 1966.

ea1c423ac86f.fact: The 10-digit ISBN format was developed by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and was published in 1970 as international standard ISO 2108 (any 9-digit SBN can be converted to a 10-digit ISBN by prefixing it with a zero).

6b2d4766cd2f.key: In the case of a single parameter, parametric equa
6b2d4766cd2f.fact: In the case of a single parameter, parametric equations are commonly used to express the trajectory of a moving point, in which case, the parameter is often, but not necessarily, time, and the point describes a curve, called a parametric curve.

0017707816cd.fact: In all cases, the equations are collectively called a parametric representation, or parametric system, or parameterization (also spelled parametrization, parametrisation) of the object.

bed969464f39.key: Sometimes the parametric equations for the individ
bed969464f39.fact: Sometimes the parametric equations for the individual scalar output variables are combined into a single parametric equation in vectors: ( x , y ) = ( cos ⁡ t , sin ⁡ t ) .

6345e82620d5.fact: {\displaystyle (x,y)=(\cos t,\sin t).} Parametric representations are generally nonunique (see the "Examples in two dimensions" section below), so the same quantities may be expressed by a number of different parameterizations.

c0079073d3a4.key: In addition to curves and surfaces, parametric equ
c0079073d3a4.fact: In addition to curves and surfaces, parametric equations can describe manifolds and algebraic varieties of higher dimension, with the number of parameters being equal to the dimension of the manifold or variety, and the number of equations being equal to the dimension of the space in which the manifold or variety is considered (for curves the dimension is one and one parameter is used, for surfaces dimension two and two parameters, etc.).

e9b478c6ed98.fact: Parametric equations are commonly used in kinematics, where the trajectory of an object is represented by equations depending on time as the parameter.

8506f97ffd80.key: Because of this application, a single parameter
8506f97ffd80.fact: Because of this application, a single parameter is often labeled t; however, parameters can represent other physical quantities (such as geometric variables) or can be selected arbitrarily for convenience.

f24742997535.fact: Parameterizations are non-unique; more than one set of parametric equations can specify the same curve.

a1844a2929c9.fact: {\textstyle \sum _{\rho \in R}\rho (x)=1.} Partitions of unity are useful because they often allow one to extend local constructions to the whole space.

28a6b8e34fa9.fact: In geometry, a point is an abstract idealization of an exact position, without size, in physical space, or its generalization to other kinds of mathematical spaces.

f172e7570580.fact: As zero-dimensional objects, points are usually taken to be the fundamental indivisible elements comprising the space, of which one-dimensional curves, two-dimensional surfaces, and higher-dimensional objects consist.

0274d70df2c7.key: In classical Euclidean geometry, a point
0274d70df2c7.fact: In classical Euclidean geometry, a point is a primitive notion, defined as "that which has no part".

2f70c48c7a0c.fact: Points and other primitive notions are not defined in terms of other concepts, but only by certain formal properties, called axioms, that they must satisfy; for example, "there is exactly one straight line that passes through two distinct points".

0929728bbf8e.fact: As physical diagrams, geometric figures are made with tools such as a compass, scriber, or pen, whose pointed tip can mark a small dot or prick a small hole representing a point, or can be drawn across a surface to represent a curve.

5df2efd9b16a.key: Since the advent of analytic geometry, points
5df2efd9b16a.fact: Since the advent of analytic geometry, points are often defined or represented in terms of numerical coordinates.

a06cd273adbe.key: In modern mathematics, a space of points
a06cd273adbe.fact: In modern mathematics, a space of points is typically treated as a set, a point set.

ea7564bffb0e.fact: An isolated point is an element of some subset of points which has some neighborhood containing no other points of the subset.

4b34e5c3d985.key: In mathematics and physics, a scalar field
4b34e5c3d985.fact: In mathematics and physics, a scalar field is a function associating a single number to each point in a region of space – possibly physical space.

d3cba87064e4.key: In a physical context, scalar fields
d3cba87064e4.fact: In a physical context, scalar fields are required to be independent of the choice of reference frame.

7375e159062f.fact: These fields are the subject of scalar field theory.

3dab6d2fe2fe.fact: In mathematics, a spline is a function defined piecewise by polynomials.

5b51da3df605.fact: In interpolating problems, spline interpolation is often preferred to polynomial interpolation because it yields similar results, even when using low degree polynomials, while avoiding Runge's phenomenon for higher degrees.

a8a7fc814e96.fact: A weight function is a mathematical device used when performing a sum, integral, or average to give some elements more "weight" or influence on the result than other elements in the same set.

63bb86707309.key: The result of this application of a weight functio
63bb86707309.fact: The result of this application of a weight function is a weighted sum or weighted average.

a685b92b3ebf.key: Weight functions occur frequently in statistics an
a685b92b3ebf.fact: Weight functions occur frequently in statistics and analysis, and are closely related to the concept of a measure.

e31b119bb00f.fact: arXiv (pronounced as "archive"—the X represents the Greek letter chi ⟨χ⟩) is an open-access repository of electronic preprints and postprints (known as e-prints) approved for posting after moderation, but not peer reviewed.

c96e4665d261.key: In many fields of mathematics and physics, almost
c96e4665d261.fact: In many fields of mathematics and physics, almost all scientific papers are self-archived on the arXiv repository before publication in a peer-reviewed journal.

17a3c062e026.key: As of November 2024, the submission rate
17a3c062e026.fact: As of November 2024, the submission rate is about 24,000 articles per month.

204e2148b30f.fact: The bibcode (also known as the refcode) is a compact identifier used by several astronomical data systems to uniquely specify literature references.

322029a2d6e5.key: In the mathematical fields of numerical analysis a
322029a2d6e5.fact: In the mathematical fields of numerical analysis and approximation theory, box splines are piecewise polynomial functions of several variables.

db2231c22e23.fact: Box splines are considered as a multivariate generalization of basis splines (B-splines) and are generally used for multivariate approximation/interpolation.

8fee17029037.fact: Geometrically, a box spline is the shadow (X-ray) of a hypercube projected down to a lower-dimensional space.

8679e275a197.fact: Box splines and simplex splines are well studied special cases of polyhedral splines which are defined as shadows of general polytopes.

07b44dcb0ec6.key: The Cauchy distribution, named after Augustin-Loui
07b44dcb0ec6.fact: The Cauchy distribution, named after Augustin-Louis Cauchy, is a continuous probability distribution.

e833696792a0.fact: The Cauchy distribution is often used in statistics as the canonical example of a "pathological" distribution since both its expected value and its variance are undefined (but see § Moments below).

f5ec5e282cd7.fact: In mathematics, it is closely related to the Poisson kernel, which is the fundamental solution for the Laplace equation in the upper half-plane.

a18a0e945bb0.fact: Chebyshev filters are analog or digital filters that have a steeper roll-off than Butterworth filters, and have either passband ripple (type I) or stopband ripple (type II).

9852990fcef1.fact: This type of filter is named after Pafnuty Chebyshev because its mathematical characteristics are derived from Chebyshev polynomials.

56d04b13d4a4.fact: Type I Chebyshev filters are usually referred to as "Chebyshev filters", while type II filters are usually called "inverse Chebyshev filters".

83804b0c01c7.key: Because of the passband ripple inherent in Chebysh
83804b0c01c7.fact: Because of the passband ripple inherent in Chebyshev filters, filters with a smoother response in the passband but a more irregular response in the stopband are preferred for certain applications.

a0b42d194ff7.key: In geometric modelling and in computer graphics, a
a0b42d194ff7.fact: In geometric modelling and in computer graphics, a composite Bézier curve or Bezier spline is a spline made out of Bézier curves that is at least C 0 {\displaystyle C^{0}} continuous.

217ad73b9f48.key: In other words, a composite Bézier curve
217ad73b9f48.fact: In other words, a composite Bézier curve is a series of Bézier curves joined end to end where the last point of one curve coincides with the starting point of the next curve.

89a4a36d7e5e.key: Perhaps the most common use of composite Béziers
89a4a36d7e5e.fact: Perhaps the most common use of composite Béziers is to describe the outline of each letter in a PostScript or PDF file.

5d032cfc3c25.fact: Such outlines are composed of one béziergon for open letters, or multiple béziergons for closed letters.

10a136d28a61.fact: CAM (computer-aided manufacturing), also known as computer-aided modeling or computer-aided machining is the use of software to control machine tools in the manufacturing of work pieces.

9d631d53a11d.fact: Its primary purpose is to create a faster production process and components and tooling with more precise dimensions and material consistency, which in some cases, uses only the required amount of raw material (thus minimizing waste), while simultaneously reducing energy consumption.

ad017e9d6654.fact: CAM is used in many schools alongside CAD to create objects.

fc7985af34e3.fact: The phrase was coined in 1960 by computer graphics researchers Verne Hudson and William Fetter of Boeing.

eb7bd98a2433.key: The non-artistic aspects of computer graphics
eb7bd98a2433.fact: The non-artistic aspects of computer graphics are the subject of computer science research.

4814347aaf7b.fact: In mathematics, a continuous function is a function such that a small variation of the argument induces a small variation of the value of the function.

393b61686ea0.key: This implies there are no abrupt changes in value
393b61686ea0.fact: This implies there are no abrupt changes in value, known as discontinuities.

194260a5cc9a.fact: More precisely, a function is continuous if arbitrarily small changes in its value can be assured by restricting to sufficiently small changes of its argument.

470e4f722eac.fact: A discontinuous function is a function that is not continuous.

5f345ec2269d.key: The epsilon–delta definition of a limit
5f345ec2269d.fact: The epsilon–delta definition of a limit was introduced to formalize the definition of continuity.

dcb7f374f7ef.fact: Continuity is one of the core concepts of calculus and mathematical analysis, where arguments and values of functions are real and complex numbers.

2b662396d7e9.fact: The latter are the most general continuous functions, and their definition is the basis of topology.

ddc97e2f6abd.fact: A stronger form of continuity is uniform continuity.

f70f3ffedfa8.key: In order theory, especially in domain theory, a re
f70f3ffedfa8.fact: In order theory, especially in domain theory, a related concept of continuity is Scott continuity.

5db79eae9601.key: In contrast, the function M(t) denoting the amount
5db79eae9601.fact: In contrast, the function M(t) denoting the amount of money in a bank account at time t would be considered discontinuous since it "jumps" at each point in time when money is deposited or withdrawn.

baca2a7f3390.key: In many texts, the coefficients a, b, c, and d
baca2a7f3390.fact: In many texts, the coefficients a, b, c, and d are supposed to be real numbers, and the function is considered as a real function that maps real numbers to real numbers or as a complex function that maps complex numbers to complex numbers.

9f00dbfc4766.key: In other cases, the coefficients may be complex nu
9f00dbfc4766.fact: In other cases, the coefficients may be complex numbers, and the function is a complex function that has the set of the complex numbers as its codomain, even when the domain is restricted to the real numbers.

54083c9c1c0c.key: Setting f(x) = 0 produces a cubic equation of the
54083c9c1c0c.fact: Setting f(x) = 0 produces a cubic equation of the form a x 3 + b x 2 + c x + d = 0 , {\displaystyle ax^{3}+bx^{2}+cx+d=0,} whose solutions are called roots of the function.

e03953818163.key: The derivative of a cubic function
e03953818163.fact: The derivative of a cubic function is a quadratic function.

a244ceaa1935.fact: Otherwise, a cubic function is monotonic.

cf3f1d7c6559.key: The graph of a cubic function
cf3f1d7c6559.fact: The graph of a cubic function is symmetric with respect to its inflection point; that is, it is invariant under a rotation of a half turn around this point.

8da4ed052d98.key: Up to an affine transformation, there
8da4ed052d98.fact: Up to an affine transformation, there are only three possible graphs for cubic functions.

d6c6a6ad4d97.fact: Cubic functions are fundamental for cubic interpolation.

95a096cb7cf6.fact: Curve fitting is the process of constructing a curve, or mathematical function, that has the best fit to a series of data points, possibly subject to constraints.

6cd3d9149378.key: Curve fitting can involve either interpolation, wh
6cd3d9149378.fact: Curve fitting can involve either interpolation, where an exact fit to the data is required, or smoothing, in which a "smooth" function is constructed that approximately fits the data.

5c4bc680b47d.fact: A related topic is regression analysis, which focuses more on questions of statistical inference such as how much uncertainty is present in a curve that is fitted to data observed with random errors.

2989b04435b8.key: Fitted curves can be used as an aid for data visua
2989b04435b8.fact: Fitted curves can be used as an aid for data visualization, to infer values of a function where no data are available, and to summarize the relationships among two or more variables.

21322cd35e5a.key: Extrapolation refers to the use of a fitted curve
21322cd35e5a.fact: Extrapolation refers to the use of a fitted curve beyond the range of the observed data, and is subject to a degree of uncertainty since it may reflect the method used to construct the curve as much as it reflects the observed data.

ddad3a18a39f.fact: Geometric fits are not popular because they usually require non-linear and/or iterative calculations, although they have the advantage of a more aesthetic and geometrically accurate result.

695e6cccb179.fact: The algorithm was devised by German-American mathematician Carl R.

7e1be565cca6.key: Simplified, potentially faster variants of the de
7e1be565cca6.fact: Simplified, potentially faster variants of the de Boor algorithm have been created but they suffer from comparatively lower stability.

38f858214e38.key: In mathematics, the degree of a polynomial
38f858214e38.fact: In mathematics, the degree of a polynomial is the highest of the degrees of the polynomial's monomials (individual terms) with non-zero coefficients.

70ff23079cd5.fact: The degree of a term is the sum of the exponents of the variables that appear in it, and thus is a non-negative integer.

0165b8a68be5.key: For a univariate polynomial, the degree of the pol
0165b8a68be5.fact: For a univariate polynomial, the degree of the polynomial is simply the highest exponent occurring in the polynomial.

9d05e092c3f2.key: Therefore, the polynomial has a degree of 5, which
9d05e092c3f2.fact: Therefore, the polynomial has a degree of 5, which is the highest degree of any term.

663f5f67c07b.fact: However, this is not needed when the polynomial is written as a product of polynomials in standard form, because the degree of a product is the sum of the degrees of the factors.

c9802c1efb05.fact: In mathematics, the derivative is a fundamental tool that quantifies the sensitivity to change of a function's output with respect to its input.

79ca3b5d7970.key: The derivative of a function of a single variable
79ca3b5d7970.fact: The derivative of a function of a single variable at a chosen input value, when it exists, is the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function at that point.

631ab794bb7c.fact: The tangent line is the best linear approximation of the function near that input value.

8e69352316f9.fact: The derivative is often described as the instantaneous rate of change, the ratio of the instantaneous change in the dependent variable to that of the independent variable.

bd934352e113.key: The process of finding a derivative
bd934352e113.fact: The process of finding a derivative is called differentiation.

3bb821e5afa9.key: Leibniz notation, named after Gottfried Wilhelm Le
3bb821e5afa9.fact: Leibniz notation, named after Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, is represented as the ratio of two differentials, whereas prime notation is written by adding a prime mark.

c9b2d16e6ab4.key: Higher order notations represent repeated differen
c9b2d16e6ab4.fact: Higher order notations represent repeated differentiation, and they are usually denoted in Leibniz notation by adding superscripts to the differentials, and in prime notation by adding additional prime marks.

bd22c27a823b.fact: Higher order derivatives are used in physics; for example, the first derivative with respect to time of the position of a moving object is its velocity, and the second derivative is its acceleration.

e58ba4281ace.fact: In this case, the derivative is reinterpreted as a linear transformation whose graph is (after an appropriate translation) the best linear approximation to the graph of the original function.

262ab47edb51.fact: The Jacobian matrix is the matrix that represents this linear transformation with respect to the basis given by the choice of independent and dependent variables.

f24ee519f0f1.fact: In mathematics, an analytic function is a function that is locally given by a convergent power series.

92b129fda2d9.fact: Functions of each type are infinitely differentiable, but complex analytic functions exhibit properties that do not generally hold for real analytic functions.

f2beb8cdc9e0.fact: In mathematics, approximation theory is concerned with how functions can best be approximated with simpler functions, and with quantitatively characterizing the errors introduced thereby.

4a2028eceac5.fact: What is meant by best and simpler will depend on the application.

959e79de827a.fact: A closely related topic is the approximation of functions by generalized Fourier series, that is, approximations based upon summation of a series of terms based upon orthogonal polynomials.

92b22a542769.fact: One problem of particular interest is that of approximating a function in a computer mathematical library, using operations that can be performed on the computer or calculator (e.g.

7a283437751a.key: addition and multiplication), such that the result
7a283437751a.fact: addition and multiplication), such that the result is as close to the actual function as possible.

a08928da2294.fact: The objective is to make the approximation as close as possible to the actual function, typically with an accuracy close to that of the underlying computer's floating point arithmetic.

d421fdce4806.fact: In mathematics, more specifically in functional analysis, a Banach space (, Polish pronunciation: [ˈba.nax]) is a complete normed vector space.

ba08c5789ff7.fact: Thus, a Banach space is a vector space with a metric that allows the computation of vector length and distance between vectors and is complete in the sense that a Cauchy sequence of vectors always converges to a well-defined limit that is within the space.

c28050f7a811.fact: Banach spaces are named after the Polish mathematician Stefan Banach, who introduced this concept and studied it systematically in 1920–1922 along with Hans Hahn and Eduard Helly.

21fa3c1f25d0.fact: Maurice René Fréchet was the first to use the term "Banach space" and Banach in turn then coined the term "Fréchet space".

370efd6493d6.key: In other areas of analysis, the spaces under study
370efd6493d6.fact: In other areas of analysis, the spaces under study are often Banach spaces.

019eb69ab1ca.key: In mathematics, a set B of elements of a vector s
019eb69ab1ca.fact: In mathematics, a set B of elements of a vector space V is called a basis (pl.: bases) if every element of V can be written in a unique way as a finite linear combination of elements of B.

88c252392ac2.key: The coefficients of this linear combination
88c252392ac2.fact: The coefficients of this linear combination are referred to as components or coordinates of the vector with respect to B.

0b692834b4d3.fact: The elements of a basis are called basis vectors.

bdc0e15968ce.fact: Equivalently, a set B is a basis if its elements are linearly independent and every element of V is a linear combination of elements of B.

a70dda228b83.fact: In other words, a basis is a linearly independent spanning set.

d93dda612b4f.fact: However, many of the principles are also valid for infinite-dimensional vector spaces.

f820c05f0ed5.fact: An example is the pair of sets of respectively left and right eigenvectors of a matrix, indexed by eigenvalue, if the eigenvalues are distinct.

d8757310ed9d.fact: A Biorthogonal wavelet is a wavelet where the associated wavelet transform is invertible but not necessarily orthogonal.

fd5d35da7095.fact: One additional degree of freedom is the possibility to construct symmetric wavelet functions.

173ff9350686.fact: The dual set is always linearly independent but does not necessarily span V ∗ {\displaystyle V^{*}} .

98631993db5e.fact: If it does span V ∗ {\displaystyle V^{*}} , then B ∗ {\displaystyle B^{*}} is called the dual basis or reciprocal basis for the basis B {\displaystyle B} .

0c4b414c73d1.fact: Finite element method (FEM) is a popular method for numerically solving differential equations arising in engineering and mathematical modeling.

524164822d03.fact: Computers are usually used to perform the calculations required.

efb7f6fad93b.key: With high-speed supercomputers, better solutions c
efb7f6fad93b.fact: With high-speed supercomputers, better solutions can be achieved and are often required to solve the largest and most complex problems.

411f822017e8.fact: FEM is a general numerical method for solving partial differential equations in two- or three-space variables (i.e., some boundary value problems).

00c621173655.key: The simple equations that model these finite eleme
00c621173655.fact: The simple equations that model these finite elements are then assembled into a larger system of equations that models the entire problem.

d1f29c688af1.key: Studying or analyzing a phenomenon with FEM
d1f29c688af1.fact: Studying or analyzing a phenomenon with FEM is often referred to as finite element analysis (FEA).

764e9f740f09.key: In mathematics, the sciences, and engineering, Fou
764e9f740f09.fact: In mathematics, the sciences, and engineering, Fourier analysis () is the study of the way general functions on the real line, circle, integers, finite cyclic group or general locally compact Abelian group may be represented or approximated by sums of trigonometric functions or more conveniently, complex exponentials.

086c25f66ff5.key: Fourier analysis grew from the study of Fourier se
086c25f66ff5.fact: Fourier analysis grew from the study of Fourier series, and is named after Joseph Fourier, who showed that representing a function as a sum of trigonometric functions greatly simplifies the study of heat transfer.

82b75d6ada00.key: while the operation of rebuilding the function fro
82b75d6ada00.fact: The process of decomposing a function into oscillatory components is often called Fourier analysis, while the operation of rebuilding the function from these pieces is known as Fourier synthesis.

64a42802a749.key: For example, determining what component frequencie
64a42802a749.fact: For example, determining what component frequencies are present in a musical note would involve computing the Fourier transform of a sampled musical note.

f89055140123.fact: The decomposition process itself is called a Fourier transformation.

d67cf000a340.fact: Its output, the Fourier transform, is often given a more specific name, which depends on the domain and other properties of the function being transformed.

a3fb4f5eccb4.key: and the general field is often
a3fb4f5eccb4.fact: Moreover, the original concept of Fourier analysis has been extended over time to apply to more and more abstract and general situations as group representation theory, and the general field is often known as harmonic analysis.

45e397c27279.fact: In applications, Fourier analysis is usually applied to a "signal" depending on "time" sampled at equal time intervals of length T {\displaystyle T} .

ea824b0ce6bd.fact: The fast Fourier transform is an efficient algorithm to compute these amplitudes.

478a7a3e58b3.fact: A Fourier series () is a series expansion of a periodic function into a sum of trigonometric functions.

a67428bc4dbc.fact: The Fourier series is an example of a trigonometric series.

3a5e401d750c.key: By expressing a function as a sum of sines and cos
3a5e401d750c.fact: By expressing a function as a sum of sines and cosines, many problems involving the function become easier to analyze because trigonometric functions are well understood.

40d6a67f2b41.fact: For example, Fourier series were first used by Joseph Fourier to find solutions to the heat equation.

349e6c574294.fact: This application is possible because the derivatives of trigonometric functions fall into simple patterns.

61756c1060ce.key: The coefficients of the Fourier series
61756c1060ce.fact: The coefficients of the Fourier series are determined by integrals of the function multiplied by trigonometric functions, described in Fourier series § Definition.

4d7d354589d6.key: The study of the convergence of Fourier series foc
4d7d354589d6.fact: The study of the convergence of Fourier series focus on the behaviors of the partial sums, which means studying the behavior of the sum as more and more terms from the series are summed.

05e261d22d64.fact: Fourier series are closely related to the Fourier transform, a more general tool that can even find the frequency information for functions that are not periodic.

fcbd663a73c6.key: Periodic functions can be identified with function
fcbd663a73c6.fact: Periodic functions can be identified with functions on a circle; for this reason Fourier series are the subject of Fourier analysis on the circle group, denoted by T {\displaystyle \mathbb {T} } or S 1 {\displaystyle S_{1}} .

dca82706eacb.key: Since Fourier's time, many different approaches to
dca82706eacb.fact: Since Fourier's time, many different approaches to defining and understanding the concept of Fourier series have been discovered, all of which are consistent with one another, but each of which emphasizes different aspects of the topic.

a111a8a359aa.key: Some of the more powerful and elegant approaches
a111a8a359aa.fact: Some of the more powerful and elegant approaches are based on mathematical ideas and tools that were not available in Fourier's time.

03efc5677384.fact: In mathematics, a function space is a set of functions between two fixed sets.

0efd707f2417.key: Often, the domain and/or codomain will have additi
0efd707f2417.fact: Often, the domain and/or codomain will have additional structure which is inherited by the function space.

931d16d05db1.key: Often in mathematical jargon, especially in analys
931d16d05db1.fact: Often in mathematical jargon, especially in analysis or geometry, a function could refer to a map of the form X → R {\displaystyle X\to \mathbb {R} } or X → C {\displaystyle X\to \mathbb {C} } where X {\displaystyle X} is the space in question.

aa4384730d27.key: Whilst other maps of the form
aa4384730d27.fact: Whilst other maps of the form X → Y {\displaystyle X\to Y} between any two spaces are simply referred to as maps.

06362b586e0c.fact: Functional analysis is a branch of mathematical analysis, the core of which is formed by the study of vector spaces endowed with some kind of limit-related structure (for example, inner product, norm, or topology) and the linear functions defined on these spaces and suitably respecting these structures.

a77fa7693b54.key: The usage of the word functional as a noun goes ba
a77fa7693b54.fact: The usage of the word functional as a noun goes back to the calculus of variations, implying a function whose argument is a function.

fccab5e93d4c.fact: The term was first used in Hadamard's 1910 book on that subject.

ba6665a2f458.fact: However, the general concept of a functional had previously been introduced in 1887 by the Italian mathematician and physicist Vito Volterra.

77a34e9486f4.fact: The theory of nonlinear functionals was continued by students of Hadamard, in particular Fréchet and Lévy.

59390b902b4f.fact: Hadamard also founded the modern school of linear functional analysis further developed by Riesz and the group of Polish mathematicians around Stefan Banach.

57706d740dcf.key: In modern introductory texts on functional analysi
57706d740dcf.fact: In modern introductory texts on functional analysis, the subject is seen as the study of vector spaces endowed with a topology, in particular infinite-dimensional spaces.

f08242e9d32c.fact: An important part of functional analysis is the extension of the theories of measure, integration, and probability to infinite-dimensional spaces, also known as infinite dimensional analysis.

4b1e00a06e4b.fact: Harmonic analysis is a branch of mathematics concerned with investigating the connections between a function and its representation in frequency.

55f97b3b33ad.fact: The frequency representation is found by using the Fourier transform for functions on unbounded domains such as the full real line or by Fourier series for functions on bounded domains, especially periodic functions on finite intervals.

90b979b7b4d4.key: Generalizing these transforms to other domains
90b979b7b4d4.fact: Generalizing these transforms to other domains is generally called Fourier analysis, although the term is sometimes used interchangeably with harmonic analysis.

f7fd024cfc9a.key: In physical eigenvalue problems, it began to mean
f7fd024cfc9a.fact: In physical eigenvalue problems, it began to mean waves whose frequencies are integer multiples of one another, as are the frequencies of the harmonics of music notes.

9257440cbb14.fact: The study of series is a major part of calculus and its generalization, mathematical analysis.

bef99584217a.fact: Series are used in most areas of mathematics, even for studying finite structures in combinatorics through generating functions.

7b0a6b825b6e.key: Among the Ancient Greeks, the idea that a potentia
7b0a6b825b6e.fact: Among the Ancient Greeks, the idea that a potentially infinite summation could produce a finite result was considered paradoxical, most famously in Zeno's paradoxes.

f7ccf76f1770.fact: Nonetheless, infinite series were applied practically by Ancient Greek mathematicians including Archimedes, for instance in the quadrature of the parabola.

e0bc0c5f91ab.key: The mathematical side of Zeno's paradoxes
e0bc0c5f91ab.fact: The mathematical side of Zeno's paradoxes was resolved using the concept of a limit during the 17th century, especially through the early calculus of Isaac Newton.

6566522addd1.fact: The resolution was made more rigorous and further improved in the 19th century through the work of Carl Friedrich Gauss and Augustin-Louis Cauchy, among others, answering questions about which of these sums exist via the completeness of the real numbers and whether series terms can be rearranged or not without changing their sums using absolute convergence and conditional convergence of series.

ffaddb691a9e.fact: To emphasize that there are an infinite number of terms, series are often also called infinite series to contrast with finite series, a term sometimes used for finite sums.

7dd89ad934bf.fact: This value is the limit as ⁠ n {\displaystyle n} ⁠ tends to infinity of the finite sums of the ⁠ n {\displaystyle n} ⁠ first terms of the series if the limit exists.

ede4f5f9c6f1.fact: These finite sums are called the partial sums of the series.

ce6947490672.fact: The expression ∑ i = 1 ∞ a i {\textstyle \sum _{i=1}^{\infty }a_{i}} denotes both the series—the implicit process of adding the terms one after the other indefinitely—and, if the series is convergent, the sum of the series—the explicit limit of the process.

67e6b488ec01.key: If so, the set of all series
67e6b488ec01.fact: If so, the set of all series is also itself a ring, one in which the addition consists of adding series terms together term by term and the multiplication is the Cauchy product.

2b5f97dcfadd.key: In mathematics, an inner product space
2b5f97dcfadd.fact: In mathematics, an inner product space is a real or complex vector space endowed with an operation called an inner product.

1e23be011f0f.key: The inner product of two vectors in the space
1e23be011f0f.fact: The inner product of two vectors in the space is a scalar, often denoted with angle brackets such as in ⟨ a , b ⟩ {\displaystyle \langle a,b\rangle } .

8180f7c6650e.key: Inner product spaces generalize Euclidean vector s
8180f7c6650e.fact: Inner product spaces generalize Euclidean vector spaces, in which the inner product is the dot product or scalar product of Cartesian coordinates.

074966ba1f43.key: Inner product spaces of infinite dimensions
074966ba1f43.fact: Inner product spaces of infinite dimensions are widely used in functional analysis.

09f136e80852.key: Inner product spaces over the field of complex num
09f136e80852.fact: Inner product spaces over the field of complex numbers are sometimes referred to as unitary spaces.

6694fa735b13.key: The first usage of the concept of a vector space w
6694fa735b13.fact: The first usage of the concept of a vector space with an inner product is due to Giuseppe Peano, in 1898.

7ac1c47412a2.key: An inner product naturally induces an associated n
7ac1c47412a2.fact: An inner product naturally induces an associated norm, (denoted | x | {\displaystyle |x|} and | y | {\displaystyle |y|} in the picture); so, every inner product space is a normed vector space.

566bb64e5f77.fact: If this normed space is also complete (that is, a Banach space) then the inner product space is a Hilbert space.

6eaee56e90ad.key: If an inner product space H
6eaee56e90ad.fact: If an inner product space H is not a Hilbert space, it can be extended by completion to a Hilbert space H ¯ .

f734842d7ca7.fact: A closely related problem is the approximation of a complicated function by a simple function.

7c0eb7e0ff01.key: Suppose the formula for some given function
7c0eb7e0ff01.fact: Suppose the formula for some given function is known, but too complicated to evaluate efficiently.

c3f0eb6aa3da.key: A few data points from the original function can b
c3f0eb6aa3da.fact: A few data points from the original function can be interpolated to produce a simpler function which is still fairly close to the original.

9726255eec08.fact: Money was historically an emergent market phenomenon that possessed intrinsic value as a commodity; nearly all contemporary money systems are based on unbacked fiat money without use value.

e745aba40fb0.fact: Its value is consequently derived by social convention, having been declared by a government or regulatory entity to be legal tender; that is, it must be accepted as a form of payment within the boundaries of the country, for "all debts, public and private", in the case of the United States dollar.

a5182e906e8b.key: The AD–AS or aggregate demand–aggregate supply mod
a5182e906e8b.fact: The AD–AS or aggregate demand–aggregate supply model (also known as the aggregate supply–aggregate demand or AS–AD model) is a widely used macroeconomic model that explains short-run and long-run economic changes through the relationship of aggregate demand (AD) and aggregate supply (AS) in a diagram.

b1019410f793.key: the change in the price level over time, which
b1019410f793.fact: the change in the price level over time, which is usually of more direct interest).

41c580c1191e.fact: The AD–AS model was invented around 1950 and became one of the primary simplified representations of macroeconomic issues toward the end of the 1970s when inflation became an important political issue.

acf96ebd8166.key: From around 2000 the modified version of a dynamic
acf96ebd8166.fact: From around 2000 the modified version of a dynamic AD–AS model, incorporating contemporary monetary policy strategies focusing on inflation targeting and using the interest rate as a primary policy instrument, was developed, gradually superseding the traditional static model version in university-level economics textbooks.

1cc3fa5775a2.key: The dynamic AD–AS model can be viewed as a simplif
1cc3fa5775a2.fact: The dynamic AD–AS model can be viewed as a simplified version of the more advanced and complex dynamic stochastic general equilibrium (DSGE) models which are state-of-the-art models used by central banks and other organizations to analyze economic fluctuations.

376a122f2b2c.key: Unlike DSGE models, the dynamic AD–AS model does n
376a122f2b2c.fact: Unlike DSGE models, the dynamic AD–AS model does not provide a microeconomic foundation in the form of optimizing firms and households, but the macroeconomic relationships ultimately posited by the optimizing models are similar to those emerging from the modern-version AD–AS model.

a888336fb1de.key: At the same time, the latter
a888336fb1de.fact: At the same time, the latter is much simpler and consequently more easily accessible for students, making it a widespread tool for teaching purposes.

f0f68c874177.fact: The accelerator effect in economics is a positive effect on private fixed investment of the growth of the market economy (measured e.g.

fde91ea782f8.fact: (This expenditure is called fixed investment.) This may lead to further growth of the economy through the stimulation of consumer incomes and purchases, i.e., via the multiplier effect.

6b6b4beeed06.key: In essence, the accelerator effect proposes that i
6b6b4beeed06.fact: In essence, the accelerator effect proposes that investment levels are contingent on the pace of change in GDP rather than its absolute level.

f8971636e33c.fact: In simpler terms, it is the acceleration or deceleration of economic growth that shapes businesses' choices regarding investments.

1d386b11cc84.key: The accelerator effect fits the behavior of an eco
1d386b11cc84.fact: The accelerator effect fits the behavior of an economy best when either the economy is moving away from full employment or when it is already below that level of production.

3b85fce04a4a.fact: 5 June] 1723 – 17 July 1790) was a Scottish economist and philosopher who was a pioneer in the field of political economy and key figure during the Scottish Enlightenment.

bcfbf3ead6eb.key: Seen by many as the "father of economics" or the "
bcfbf3ead6eb.fact: Seen by many as the "father of economics" or the "father of capitalism", he is primarily known for two classic works: The Theory of Moral Sentiments (1759) and An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations (1776).

8449576cee69.key: The latter, often abbreviated as The Wealth of Nat
8449576cee69.fact: The latter, often abbreviated as The Wealth of Nations, is regarded as his magnum opus, marking the inception of modern economic scholarship as a comprehensive system and an academic discipline.

4d9e303bee9b.fact: The work is notable for its contribution to economic theory, particularly in its exposition of the concept of absolute advantage.

243e9169ce4a.key: Born in Kirkcaldy, Fife, he studied social philoso
243e9169ce4a.fact: Born in Kirkcaldy, Fife, he studied social philosophy at the University of Glasgow and at the University of Oxford, where he was one of the only students to benefit from scholarships set up by John Snell.

2aeb31275089.key: a practice that came to be
2aeb31275089.fact: In response to the prevailing policy of safeguarding national markets and merchants through the reduction of imports and the augmentation of exports, a practice that came to be known as mercantilism, Smith laid the foundational principles of classical free-market economic theory.

521f909fedd9.fact: The Wealth of Nations was a precursor to the modern academic discipline of economics.

a66e44736e75.fact: Smith was controversial in his day and his general approach and writing style were often satirised by writers such as Horace Walpole.

c9a6a2bb4465.fact: In economics, adaptive expectations is a hypothesized process by which people form their expectations about what will happen in the future based on what has happened in the past.

f0b55cfac44f.key: This says that current expectations of future infl
f0b55cfac44f.fact: This says that current expectations of future inflation reflect past expectations and an "error-adjustment" term, in which current expectations are raised (or lowered) according to the gap between actual inflation and previous expectations.

efbc8644600e.fact: λ ( p − p − 1 e ) {\displaystyle \lambda (p-p_{-1}^{e})} The above term is the partial adjustment error term, this term allows for variances that occur between actual values and expected values.

d4843a39a72e.fact: This consideration or error term is what allows the predicted value to be adaptable, thus creating an equation that is adaptive of the expectation being inferred.

da7400408029.key: The backward nature of expectation formulation and
da7400408029.fact: The backward nature of expectation formulation and the resultant systematic errors made by agents (see cobweb model) had become unsatisfactory to economists such as John Muth, who was pivotal in the development of an alternative model of how expectations are formed, called rational expectations.

0b03d828074c.key: The use of rational expectations have largely repl
0b03d828074c.fact: The use of rational expectations have largely replaced adaptive expectations in macroeconomic theory since its assumptions rely on an optimal expectations approach which is consistent with economic theory.

ccfe14621059.key: However, it must be stressed that confronting adap
ccfe14621059.fact: However, it must be stressed that confronting adaptive expectations and rational expectations aren't necessarily justified by either use, in other words, there are situations in which following the adaptive scheme is a rational response.

b602f6a6ffd4.key: The first use adaptive expectations hypothesis
b602f6a6ffd4.fact: The first use adaptive expectations hypothesis was to describe agent behavior in The Purchasing Power of Money by Irving Fisher (1911), then later used to describe models such as hyperinflation by Philip Cagan (1956).

aee333a48370.fact: Adaptive expectations were instrumental in the consumption function (1957) and Phillips curve outlined by Milton Friedman.

58b5b0b52380.fact: As agents are trapped by the money illusion, they are unable to correctly perceive price and wage dynamics, so based on Friedman's theory, unemployment can always be reduced through monetary expansions.

b1b211fd790f.key: If the government chooses to fix a low unemploymen
b1b211fd790f.fact: If the government chooses to fix a low unemployment rate the result is an increasing level of inflation for an extended period of time.

3dc99016d660.fact: Agent-based computational economics (ACE) is the area of computational economics that studies economic processes, including whole economies, as dynamic systems of interacting agents.

f7b37ced0152.fact: In corresponding agent-based models, the "agents" are "computational objects modeled as interacting according to rules" over space and time, not real people.

c2cb8320f5a2.fact: The rules are formulated to model behavior and social interactions based on incentives and information.

8b2523c5ed44.key: As part of non-equilibrium economics, the theoreti
8b2523c5ed44.fact: As part of non-equilibrium economics, the theoretical assumption of mathematical optimization by agents in equilibrium is replaced by the less restrictive postulate of agents with bounded rationality adapting to market forces.

fd9a953805b9.key: But practitioners have also noted differences from
fd9a953805b9.fact: But practitioners have also noted differences from standard methods, for example in ACE events modeled being driven solely by initial conditions, whether or not equilibria exist or are computationally tractable, and in the modeling facilitation of agent autonomy and learning.

245fe5f7661c.key: In economics, aggregate demand (AD) or domestic fi
245fe5f7661c.fact: In economics, aggregate demand (AD) or domestic final demand (DFD) is the total demand for final goods and services in an economy at a given time.

f150a21327f3.fact: The aggregate demand curve is plotted with real output on the horizontal axis and the price level on the vertical axis.

64a6717a6bfd.fact: While it is theorized to be downward sloping, the Sonnenschein–Mantel–Debreu results show that the slope of the curve cannot be mathematically derived from assumptions about individual rational behavior.

bbf1f92b0b58.key: Instead, the downward sloping aggregate demand cur
bbf1f92b0b58.fact: Instead, the downward sloping aggregate demand curve is derived with the help of three macroeconomic assumptions about the functioning of markets: Pigou's wealth effect, Keynes' interest rate effect and the Mundell–Fleming exchange-rate effect.

737b979886dc.fact: The Mundell–Fleming exchange-rate effect is an extension of the IS–LM model.

fd0ca8cf2c21.key: The aggregate demand curve illustrates the relatio
fd0ca8cf2c21.fact: The aggregate demand curve illustrates the relationship between two factors: the quantity of output that is demanded and the aggregate price level.

0edd1abb6ba2.fact: Aggregate demand is expressed contingent upon a fixed level of the nominal money supply.

cdbc36f4f956.key: According to the aggregate demand-aggregate supply
cdbc36f4f956.fact: According to the aggregate demand-aggregate supply model, when aggregate demand increases, there is movement up along the aggregate supply curve, giving a higher level of prices.

1092f521aee6.key: In economics, aggregate supply (AS) or domestic fi
1092f521aee6.fact: In economics, aggregate supply (AS) or domestic final supply (DFS) is the total supply of goods and services that firms in a national economy plan on selling during a specific time period.

618bef5a265b.fact: Alan Greenspan (born March 6, 1926) is an American economist who served as the 13th chairman of the Federal Reserve from 1987 to 2006.

84c3add422eb.key: First nominated to the Federal Reserve by Presiden
84c3add422eb.fact: First nominated to the Federal Reserve by President Ronald Reagan in August 1987, Greenspan was reappointed at successive four-year intervals until retiring on January 31, 2006, after the second-longest tenure in the position, behind only William McChesney Martin.

67ce6bcbc5c3.fact: Although he was subdued in his public appearances, favorable media coverage raised his profile to a point that several observers likened him to a "rock star".

05228b4dd859.fact: Many have argued that the "easy-money" policies of the Fed during Greenspan's tenure, including the practice known as the "Greenspan put", were a leading cause of the dot-com bubble and subprime mortgage crisis (the latter occurring within a year of his leaving the Fed), which, said The Wall Street Journal, "tarnished his reputation".

dd793397c1c1.key: Greenspan has argued that the housing bubble
dd793397c1c1.fact: Greenspan has argued that the housing bubble was not a result of low-interest short-term rates but rather a worldwide phenomenon caused by the progressive decline in long-term interest rates – a direct consequence of the relationship between high savings rates in the developing world and its inverse in the developed world.

d4aaa1a60a24.fact: Alfred Marshall (26 July 1842 – 13 July 1924) was an English economist and one of the most influential economists of his time.

f9ffdf3c20d5.fact: His book Principles of Economics (1890) was the dominant economic textbook in England for many years, and brought the ideas of supply and demand, marginal utility, and costs of production into a coherent whole, popularizing the modern neoclassical approach which dominates microeconomics to this day.

1eeae1ba5e38.fact: As a result, he is known as the father of scientific economics.

d6e5dc516a6a.fact: Alvin Harvey Hansen (August 23, 1887 – June 6, 1975) was an American economist who taught at the University of Minnesota and was later a chair professor of economics at Harvard University.

b55f76a17b8d.key: Often referred to as "the American Keynes", he
b55f76a17b8d.fact: Often referred to as "the American Keynes", he was a widely read popular author on economic issues, and an influential advisor to the government on economic policy.

a7530f617616.fact: Ancient Egypt was a cradle of civilization concentrated along the lower reaches of the Nile River in Northeast Africa.

de95f37f1111.key: It emerged from prehistoric Egypt around 3150 BC (
de95f37f1111.fact: It emerged from prehistoric Egypt around 3150 BC (according to conventional Egyptian chronology), when Upper and Lower Egypt were united by Menes, who is believed by the majority of Egyptologists to have been the same person as Narmer.

fee0ad033acf.key: The pinnacle of ancient Egyptian power
fee0ad033acf.fact: The pinnacle of ancient Egyptian power was achieved during the New Kingdom, which extended its rule to much of Nubia and a considerable portion of the Levant.

b4dcce4a7212.key: Over the course of its history, it
b4dcce4a7212.fact: Over the course of its history, it was invaded or conquered by a number of foreign civilizations, including the Hyksos, the Kushites, the Assyrians, the Persians, and the Greeks and then the Romans.

fde7511fb64b.fact: The end of ancient Egypt is variously defined as occurring with the end of the Late Period during the Wars of Alexander the Great in 332 BC or with the end of the Greek-ruled Ptolemaic Kingdom during the Roman conquest of Egypt in 30 BC.

cb7039a03d05.fact: Motivating and organizing these activities was a bureaucracy of elite scribes, religious leaders, and administrators under the control of the reigning pharaoh, who ensured the cooperation and unity of the Egyptian people in the context of an elaborate system of religious beliefs.

77d200fce60e.key: Among the many achievements of ancient Egypt are:
77d200fce60e.fact: Among the many achievements of ancient Egypt are: the quarrying, surveying, and construction techniques that supported the building of monumental pyramids, temples, and obelisks; a system of mathematics; a practical and effective system of medicine; irrigation systems and agricultural production techniques; the first known planked boats; Egyptian faience and glass technology; new forms of literature; and the earliest known peace treaty, which was ratified with the Anatolia-based Hittite Empire.

cdf9bcfe26b9.fact: Its art and architecture were widely copied and its antiquities were carried off to be studied, admired, or coveted in the far corners of the world.

5fe398373e27.fact: However, The New York Times warned the next week that the word "glut" was misleading, and that temporary surpluses had brought down prices somewhat, but prices were still well above pre-energy crisis levels.

eafc34789e7e.fact: This sentiment was echoed in November 1981, when the CEO of Exxon also characterized the glut as a temporary surplus, and that the word "glut" was an example of "our American penchant for exaggerated language".

b328693f1e58.key: He wrote that the main cause of the glut
b328693f1e58.fact: He wrote that the main cause of the glut was declining consumption.

8e574ee40143.key: The 1990s economic boom in the United States
8e574ee40143.fact: The 1990s economic boom in the United States was a major economic expansion that lasted between 1993 and 2001, coinciding with the economic policies of the Clinton administration.

d5a21fd6259a.fact: Until July 2019, it was the longest recorded economic expansion in the history of the United States.

c8e545d75ba5.fact: The 1991 Indian economic crisis was an economic crisis in India resulting from a balance of payments deficit due to excess reliance on imports and other external factors.

b0e7223f2c16.fact: India's economic problems started worsening in 1985 as imports swelled, leaving the country in a twin deficit: the Indian trade balance was in deficit at a time when the government was running on a huge fiscal deficit (although the twin-deficit hypothesis is disputed).

ff0db3cf1c7e.fact: The Soviet Union was India's largest trading partner until 1991, with bilateral trade of over $5 billion per year, the turmoil in USSR triggered the collapse in India's export.

550e9b9c0b89.fact: India's foreign exchange reserves were not enough to finance three weeks' worth of imports.

be7d10ba49d8.fact: Meanwhile, the government was on the brink of defaulting on its financial obligations.

bf650a37ce81.fact: The aim of this move was to secure much-needed foreign exchange to meet India's debt obligations and stabilize the economy.

dc4135b70a6f.fact: However, this decision was not without controversy and was seen by some as a drastic and desperate move.

45a090c05e01.fact: As a result, the Indian economy was opened up to foreign participation in various sectors, including state-owned enterprises.

8c7286a65728.fact: Amos Nathan Tversky (Hebrew: עמוס טברסקי; March 16, 1937 – June 2, 1996) was an Israeli cognitive and mathematical psychologist and a key figure in the discovery of systematic human cognitive bias and handling of risk.

21c40ec0f887.fact: His early work with Daniel Kahneman focused on the psychology of prediction and probability judgment; later they worked together to develop prospect theory, which aims to explain irrational human economic choices and is considered one of the seminal works of behavioral economics.
